annotation.TEXT: Thankfully, it won't be quite as painful to play-through or watch as the DOS remake either. I honestly think there's quite a bit of entertainment value to take from this (similar to the explosively horrendous Mega Man Origins game). It also won't take nearly as long as this one did (mainly due to a combination of real life factors, and in that this game has a save feature).

Despite the simple changes to the bosses not amounting to much so far, Tako Trash still manages to find a way to annoy me. His firing rate is much faster, meaning he can flood a good portion of the screen with projectiles. The new version of the spheres he fires also bounce up and float into the air after hitting the ground.

Naturally, I'll be all over that once it gets released. For now however, there's a few other potential games to address here. There's the obvious matter of Unlimited's update, which I'm still not feeling too inclined on doing (even though I hated my old playthrough of it). Then there's SFXMM, which I'm sort of "meh" about in general. Granted, it's not like I won't do either of these games in the future, but for now, I feel like I don't have much to contribute on either of them.
Eddie shows up again to help restock for the boss rush. I won't bother showing you the process of doing so (or the boss refights themselves, for that matter). Time for the usual transition effects.
For now, I suggest you brace yourself until then (either that, or go watch HeavySigh's playthrough of Mega Man Unlimited, or at least what's uploaded of it so far).

However, there is one other game I had in mind. Similar to Mega Man 4 Plus, this game has virtually no coverage on YouTube at the moment (there are a few videos showing small portions of it here and there, but as far as I can tell, there's no full playthrough of it yet).

I have to say, the Wily map theme used here sounds very familiar. One of the sources I looked to listed it as coming from Final Fantasy VI, which could sound about right, but it's been so long since I've played that game that I honestly don't know what track it's from. In the very least, I can identify the stage theme (though I'm sure everyone else watching this could as well).

The Wily Capsule is a little bit more predictable than it was in the original. Although it has a new attack where the forming orbs actually fire out, they also serve as a hint for where the capsule is going to show up.

Tsukikuro seems to have a bit of a pattern, where he first releases a stand-alone hack, and then works on an entry in his Claw series under the same game (for example: Burst Chaser, then Rockman 3 Claw). I'd wager to guess that it could be considered practicing or experimenting for his series, but either way, we can probably expect Rockman 4 Claw to be next.

The Giant Metool isn't really all that different (once again, much like the rest of the bosses in this hack). The start-up time for his jumping is much faster, and the smaller metools he summons can jump around a bit.

It's a stand-alone, Mega Man styled game of sorts that uses different characters and resources for its presentation (although it may as well just be called a Mega Man fan-game, given how much of those resources and functions are outright ripped from the original system). It's also quite bad; I wouldn't rate it as low as the Mega Man DOS Remake, but it's definitely on the same level as Mega Man Rocks.

Well, that took longer than it probably should have. Even though I wasn't able to upload as frequently as I used to with this playthrough, I still had a fun time with this hack. Tsukikuro always seems to deliver with some fun aspects to these, and most of them don't even have overly extensive changes.
